Summary: An independent private company formed in 1994, specialising in the design and manufacture of a wide range of emergency lighting conversion kits solely for the OEM market. All Liteplan conversion kits are designed and manufactured to conform to the relevant emergency lighting product standard BS EN 61347-2-7, and all conversion work carried out at Liteplan is to meet the relevant requirements of BS EN 60598-1 (Luminaires Part 1: General requirements and tests) and BS EN 60598.2.22 (Luminaires for emergency lighting) as well as the relevant ICEL standards especially ICEL1004: (Requirements for the Re-Engineering of Luminaires for Emergency Lighting Use). We employ over 70 personnel and maintain a 'Next Day' delivery policy for conversion kits ‚Äì normally any order received before noon will be dispatched for delivery the following day. 20 years of Reliability By Design.

The company carried out celebrations for 5 Cities, being Liverpool, Belfast, Newcastle Upon Tyne, Leeds and Southampton. The early part of this millennium saw a change in the market place away from existing lighting technology and on to energy efficient light sources. The company saw this as a great opportunity as the LED light source had synergy with the companies earlier laser diode research and experience. To better prepare for this change a new sales strategy was drawn up that included the company name change to i-vision (uk) ltd

Summary: I‚Äôve spent over 30 years in the Fit out industry and have seen a number of seismic changes in my working environment and of course, in society. But one event took place in 2018 which dwarves the rest and it‚Äôs one that I certainly wasn‚Äôt prepared for. My trip to the Arctic was a memorable experience but nothing had prepared me for what was to come and how this event really did change my life. During the expedition I came face to face with the downstream effects of plastic pollution and global warming. I saw life in its harshest form and learnt from the many scientists and experts through a series of lectures which would take place each evening following the day‚Äôs activity.  As a result of this experience I have found it difficult to adapt to ‚Äònormal life‚Äô. People say I‚Äôve had an epiphany and that may well be true but one thing is for sure, my life will never be the same again My focus is now well and truly directed on the environment and ways in which I can make a difference in the industry where I‚Äôve spent most of my working life. I am doing this in two parts. Firstly, I have redoubled our efforts at Aztec to ensure we are doing as much as possible to reduce our environmental impact, minimise waste and recycle - across all aspects of the business.   This work will continue as we educate our staff and clients in the crucial role we all have to play if we‚Äôre not going to destroy this amazing planet and the creatures we share it with. The second part is through a new organisation I have established with support from the University of Liverpool called `Changing Streams CIC`. We are a 'not for profit' organisation focused on eradicating plastics at source, in the first instance within the construction sector. Our aims and objectives can be seen on our new website. By reducing the amount of plastic being used we can, and will make a positive impact in reducing waste going to landfill or worse still, into the ocean.  Please join us in whichever way you feel able.

Summary: Dr. Jabi earned his B.Arch. from the American University of Beirut and his M.Arch. and Ph.D. in architecture from the University of Michigan.  His research interests and expertise are at the intersection of parametric design, the representation of space, building performance simulation, and robotic fabrication in architecture. During the period 1996 to 2008, Dr. Jabi led the Association for Computer-Aided Design in Architecture (ACADIA), secured a $250,000 National Science Foundation (NSF) grant to study design creativity, and taught at various universities before moving to the UK in 2008. He is currently a Reader (tenured Associate Professor) at the Welsh School of Architecture, Cardiff University where he leads the digital design area. Dr. Jabi has published widely on topics ranging from parametric and generative design to the role of light in architecture and building performance simulation. He is a member of the editorial board of the International Journal of Architectural Computing (IJAC). In 2013, Dr. Jabi authored the book ‚ÄúParametric Design for Architecture‚Äù (Laurence King Publishing, London). Dr. Jabi secured a ¬£70,000 ($100,000 USD) grant to purchase a large 6-axis high accuracy industrial robot to investigate innovative digital fabrication processes of architectural components and structures and has since published several papers on his research. In 2016, Dr. Jabi secured a ¬£300,000 ($420,000 USD) grant from the Leverhulme Trust for a Research Project Grant titled ‚ÄúEnhancing the representation of architectural space in 3D modelling environments‚Äù. In this project, the team will develop a conceptual framework and schema for the hierarchical and cellular spatial representation of buildings through a concept called non-manifold topology and a set of algorithms and tools that test the potential of this approach. They will conduct four use case scenarios in the areas of: Energy Analysis, Structural Analysis, Spatial Reasoning, and Fabrication Planning.

This resulted in running laser shows at raves on the London underground party scene and meeting and working with some truly wonderful creative people. Eventually this become a full time job and business. I have also re-discovered my love and passion for playing the piano and have a new (smaller) home studio, that now includes a Moog Etherwave Theremin. Which I play ..badly! Although my 1950s B movie UFO soundscapes are pretty good‚Ä¶ And now... Designing, supplying, programming and operating stage and production lighting for shows, events, festivals.... To make each job as special as the last. To always be as creative as possible, without being constrained by budget. Specialties: Operating a show live and on the fly, busking it! Not knowing what's going to happen next, having to predict what's coming up by listening to where the music is going. Being ready and able to adapt to the moment. I am an experienced Avolites programmer and Pearl Expert owner, along with a T1 for smaller events. For the last 5 years I've been collecting and refurbishing vintage Strand theatre lights, it's become a bit of a passion!

Summary: Lighting affects our mood, impacts on our wellbeing, improves productivity and can keep us safe. The team at Waveguide Lighting believe that everyone should have the best lit environment achievable ‚Äì whether that is at work, in public places or on the streets. Waveguide Lighting is an award-winning lighting manufacturer based in Greater Manchester, and the only LED manufacturer to shine light sideways into encapsulation avoiding direct contact with the eye and providing a safe and efficient light output. We also use acrylic rods to amplify and control the light output, reducing the number of LEDs required.  This means we can use high power LEDs, draw less current and have no need to diffuse the output. Our patented lighting technology uses two-thirds of the energy of other LED competitors. Waveguide Lighting has an LED footprint for every lighting solution. We also pride ourselves for being at the forefront of LED technology, doing what others simply cannot do. Unlike other LED lighting manufacturers our team of experts can create a bespoke or retrofit lighting solution for every application.  We actively listen to our customers to ensure we deliver the exact solution that they have asked for.

Summary: Proven technical enthusiast with a keen eye for quality, consistency, clarity and maximum efficiency. In 2012 I programmed the underlying KNX and DALI building automation systems that run The Crystal, one of the greenest buildings in the world, a year after graduating with a degree in Computer Science from Loughborough University. The Crystal since went on to be a finalist for the Best International KNX Project in the category Europe at the KNX Awards 2014, and won KNX Installation of the Year at the KNX UK Annual Awards 2014. Since then amongst other wide ranging projects, I have led the engineering of 3,500 KNX devices and 6,000 DALI light fittings at the Northumbria Specialist Emergency Care Hospital, and implemented HTML-based web apps to allow dynamic control of lighting and blinds from mobiles and tablets at the RIBA Stirling Prize winning Newport Street Gallery, and at the headquarters of the Red Bull Racing F1 team in Milton Keynes. In recent years I have worked very closely with the developers at Tridium, offering advice and recommendations on the new KNX driver for the Niagara Framework, along with pioneering in house web-based validation tools that validate KNX, DALI and Niagara programming against a set of defined naming convention rules and CAD drawings, to wipe out human error. In addition to this, I've architected from scratch a set of head end graphic generation tools that are used to automate the production of lighting graphics; reducing weeks of work into hours, and at the same time removing all scope for human error. Find more details of projects that I've worked on in the Projects section below.

Summary: Research Summary: Dr Farooq Sher current research overviews the diverse range of approaches and technologies to minimise emissions of carbon dioxide (CO2) a greenhouse gas from the use of fossil fuels (coal, oil and gas). It also includes developing technologies to remove carbon dioxide from the flue gases of power plants and chimneys, as well as burn the fuels in pure oxygen (Oxy-fuel), which results in a flue gas that consists entirely of carbon dioxide and water vapours that can be captured relatively easily and can be stored safely in repositories deep underground. Moreover, He is working towards sustainable energy, environment, climate change and low carbon technologies. The main interests are in the conversion of renewable sources such as biomass, solar, wind and hydro into heat and power including their impact on the environment and climate change. He is also studying the combustion behaviour of different fossil fuels to get a better understanding of their environmental impacts. His expertises are in energy, heat and mass transfer operations, fluid mixing, distillation, energy optimisation, wastewater treatment, hydrogen production, fluidised bed combustion (FBC), life cycle assessment (LCA), oxy-fuel combustion, carbon capture and storage (CCS) and computational fluid dynamics (CFD) modelling.

Summary: As a Director and Urbanism leader for McGregor Coxall Michael brings a passion that rests in creating healthy, sustainable, and vibrant places and cities. A key part of his design journey has been my research into understanding the vital systems that combine to form a place. Through working on an array of complex projects in the UK, Australia, China and USA he has been able to discern these vital systems into a workable set of criteria that can be applied to any ‚Äòplace‚Äô. Referred to as ‚ÄòPlace Vitality Criteria‚Äô the criteria reveal a holistic set of nine systems that inter-relate with each other. This place focused ethos centred around community led regeneration has culminated in a number of recent International and Australian Urban Design, Landscape Architecture and Community Engagement awards for Parramatta City River, Byron Bay Town Centre Masterplan and Maitland High Street. All projects were large scale, environmentally constrained, highly significant to their local communities and subject to intense public scrutiny. Since moving back to the UK in 2016 Michael has embarked on a new challenge in establishing McGregor Coxall‚Äôs UK and European presence. Summary: Claire Farrell Artistic Director | Curator FRSA, MA claire@werk.org.uk My research and interests are rooted in the interdisciplinarity potential of situated art practice in urban planning and design. Taking influence from the Situationists, Artist Placement Group, Bauhaus, and Earthworks, I am interested in the transformative possibilities of collaborative practice in shaping place-based policy and planning service reform. Between 2018 and 2020 I undertook an extensive research period to examine the opportunities and limitations within the current UK planning system for planning policy and service reform. The research focussed on a number of key areas including collaborative design practice, health inequalities relating to areas of high deprivation, and importantly, how environmental planning can affect mental health and wellbeing. The research was supported through a placement with Birmingham City Council, and the findings will be explored through pilot activity that will explore community consultation methodologies and future opportunities through the devolution of decision-making processes. In addition to WERK I have held the following positions and memberships - former Art and Urbanism Specialist Panel Member for Birmingham Design and ‚Ä®Conservation Review Panel which consisted of appointed professionals who share expertise to independently and objectively assess key development proposals received by Birmingham City Council, Elected Fellow of Royal Society for the encouragement of Arts, Manufacturers and Commerce (RSA), which aims to enrich society through ideas and action, Member of Lighting Urban Community International (LUCI) a unique international network bringing together cities and lighting professionals engaged in using light as a major tool for sustainable urban, social and economic development and Visiting Lecturer in Cultural Planning, Art Policy, Stakeholder Theory for Birmingham City University. Through much-valued project funding and bursary support from the British Council and Birmingham City Council, I have developed projects, platforms for knowledge exchange and artist exchange opportunities with organisations and municipalities in the following European and International cities over the last decade; Berlin, Lyon, Paris, Leipzig, Lund, Barcelona, Rotterdam, Turin, Chicago, Los Angeles, Mumbai, Guangzhou, Hong Kong, Shanghai, and New Zealand.

Summary: For many years I have been freelancing in IT projects, solving problems and developing new ideas and solutions. Photography has been a passion for most of my life, from black and white film to the latest digital technology. IT and photography come together in interactive panoramas and virtual tours, the main business of my business, Harald Joergens Photography. Panoramas are a great marketing tool. They look cool on a website, they are much talked about on social media, and links to them are shared a lot. They are good for business. A panorama can contain an enormous amount of information. This information pops up when the viewer moves the cursor near an area of interest, so only the information the viewer is interested in does pop up. There is no information overload; the viewer is always in charge. Unlike watching a video, where the viewer can only stop and reverse or repeat a fixed sequence, a panorama leaves the viewer in total control - to move in any direction, to zoom in to inspect minute detail, to zoom out for an overview. A Virtual Tour combines two or more panoramas, allowing the viewer to 'walk through' a building, an aircraft, a ship, a golf course, it could be anything. There can me a map to help with navigation, and arrows lead from one panorama to the next. Panoramas work on almost all devices, from a smartphone to a power computer. When properly done, they load very quickly. A panorama puts the viewer into the centre of a scene. The viewer is actively in charge, not a passive consumer. That's why people love panoramas. And that makes them brilliant marketing tools. Please get in contact to discuss how a panorama can work for you and for your business: By phone: +44 (0) 1737 822 092 and +44 (0) 7903 760 948,  By email:  Harald@HaraldJoergens.com, Visit         www.HaraldJoergens.com

Summary: I was always attracted from the idea of being an entrepreneur, since my Architectural studies at Turin Politecnico I started my personal professional experience with some other fellows in the University. With few of them I founded my own Engineering firm in 2000, which I left only in 2012.  After my Engineering firm experience, I started in Proger as Project Manager for two Projects in Iraq. Few months later, I was asked to follow in Riyadh (KSA) another project for the fit out of 34 storey high building. During this experience I helped the Branch to organize the starting business. We were challenged by the growing number of employees - we reached more than 1000 units - and the complexity of the organization management.  In six months I was Chief Operating Officer and at the end of 2016 I was appointed Branch Manager Deputy for the Riyadh Branch and Business Development Manager for the Middle East area.  In 2014 I founded with my brother Paolo Superstile Ltd, a London-based advisoring company in the field of development and management of real estate assets and infrastructure projects. In the same year Ultraspazio project was born - where I am founder and partner - our Turin coworking with a drive for internationalization, in a few years one of the most important realities in the sector at city level. Since 2018 I am also founder and partner of Samos CCP Ltd, a London consultancy and services company, which acts as a bridge between the Arab and the European world on real estate development and prop-tech. Samos recently closed an agreement with EXIM Finance in Dubai to follow the assessment of the projects and the subsequent phases of Project and Construction Management of the various initiatives promoted by the Emirate company all over the world with the contribution of the European Export Credit Agencies. I live between London, Turin and the countries where we have ongoing projects. I love Turin and I have built together with some business friends a spontaneous think tank which, feeling strong the desire and responsibility to guarantee our children and future generations the opportunity to live, grow and work in a prosperous territory open to Europe and in the world, it is scientifically investigating the deep dynamics related to the decline of the city by comparing them with other Italian and European cities. I have good relationship skills and four languages spoken and written (Italian, English, French and Spanish).

Summary: In a Career starting at The London Film School and The National Film School, where I was proud to have my graduation film shown at the London Film Festival, through to Camera Assistant working on a number of Film/TV Commercials, Documentary and High Profile Feature Films, to Lighting Cameraman and eventually Director of Photography I can safely say I have experienced it all.  Even after graduating as a fully fledged Cameraman/DoP, I made a conscious decision to start at the bottom of the ladder again within the industry to gain contacts, experience and especially that very special knowledge that Film Schools cannot give you. My passion for Photography and Film started after seeing that ground-breaking Cousteau film, Le Monde du Silence at the age of 9. Although barely touching or specialising in the underwater world, I was led on to a fascinating Career path in all the types of film/tv genres mentioned above visiting all the corners of the world and subsequently experiencing the huge range of differing lifestyles of the peoples of those places. I have a particular love and interest for Africa though, having been born in Morocco and travelled and worked fairly frequently in many of it‚Äôs countries. Of course my industry is forever changing not always for the better. Schedules are often tough and budgets ever decreasing. Demand for quality is a constant but maintaining it, is in my opinion, an ever-growing struggle.  But for those of us who, like myself, pride ourselves on producing the high standard of work required of us, often with few resources, the workplace is often tough. Our huge resources of experience over decades of practising our trade does count for everything.  At the end of a beautiful African day though,  I love what I do and can honestly say, I wouldn‚Äôt change it for the world! Summary: Eujin is the Director for Postgraduate Research, and Director of the BSc Product Design Engineering Programme at Brunel University London. He specializes in New Product Development and Additive Manufacturing. He is a Chartered Engineer (CEng) and a Chartered Technological Product Designer (CTPD). As a Product Design Engineer during the early days of his career, he developed solutions for companies including Motorola, Inc., LM Ericsson, Sennheiser GmbH & Co. KG, and Rentokil Initial. Eujin's Research focuses on Additive Manufacturing. He is Chair of the British Standards Institute AMT/8 Committee for Additive Manufacturing; and the Convenor of the International Organisation for Standardisation ISO/TC261/WG4 that develops Standards for Additive Manufacturing Data and Design; and Convenor of ISO/TC261/JG67 for Functionally Graded Additive Manufacturing. Eujin is a Full Member of the EPSRC Peer Review College as the National agency that assesses proposals for funding Research in Engineering. He is a Member of the EPSRC Engineering Prioritisation Panel. In 2018, he became a Member of the EPSRC Early Career Forum in Manufacturing Research that involves participating in strategic advisory activities. Eujin is the External Examiner for Cranfield University and the University of East London. He is the Editor in Chief for the Progress in Additive Manufacturing Journal (Springer), Associate Editor for Journal of Intelligent Manufacturing (Springer) and Associate Editor for Assembly Automation Journal (Emerald). External sources of funding include the Arts and Humanities Research Council (AHRC); the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC); the Royal Academy of Engineering (RAE); Higher Education Funding Council for England (HEFCE); the British Council; and from the European Commission. Eujin currently leads two European funded projects as WP Leader, a Newton grant, two GCRF projects, and two InnovateUK projects. In 2020, Eujin was appointed as a Trustee and a Co-Opted Council Member of the Institution of Engineering Designers (IED). He is a member of the Registration Standards Committee (RSC) within the Engineering Council; Member of the Institution of Engineering Designers (MIED); Fellow of the Higher Education Academy (FHEA); and Member of the Design Research Society (DRS). In 2018, Eujin was appointed as an Erskine Fellow at the University of Canterbury in New Zealand. Joint supervision, industry partnerships and collaborative research are very welcomed. Summary: I set up DO-Architecture in 2005 which is interested in making architecture that is shaped by and made for people and communities. I believe that the process of making architecture is equally important as the resulting artefact, and actively encourage participation, experimentation and diversity to create an architecture which is appropriate to it's place and users, and is able to adapt, evolve and age gracefully in balance with it's context. Our primary architectural aspiration at DO is to create new buildings and spaces, and to re-model the existing built environment, however we also take up the challenge of reacting to man-made environments and spaces that have been created, altered, deposited or abandoned by others, and for this we use illumination and intervention. In my career to date I have worked on a range of high profile residential projects, from large-scale social and private developments to smaller bespoke projects, while also gaining extensive experience in cultural, healthcare and commercial work, most notably helping roll out the Fopp brand across the UK.

Summary: Personal Website: www.edwardthompson.co.uk Senior Lecturer: https://www.uca.ac.uk/staff-profiles/edward-thompson/ Ed Thompson is a British photographer, artist and lecturer. His own photographic work has focused on various subjects over the years from covering environmental issues, socio-political movements, subcultures and the consequences of war.  His documentary photo-essays have been published in international magazines including National Geographic Magazine, Newsweek Japan, Greenpeace Magazine, The Guardian Weekend Magazine and The Sunday Times Magazine Spectrum Supplement (U.K). His work has been exhibited at Christies, Somerset House and Four Corners Gallery (London) and shown as part of photography festivals in Arles (France), Tampere (Finland), Zingst (Germany) & London (U.K).    LECTURES & INTERVIEWS 2015 In March 2015 Ed was interviewed about photographic manipulation and ethics in photojournalism live on Newshour on the BBC World Service.  2014 In December 2014 Ed Thompson spoke about his work with Occupy at the V&A Museum (London). In November 2014 he became an Associate Lecturer at The London College of Communication. In Spring 2014 he worked as a visiting Lecturer at The University of Bedfordshire where he lectured on his own work, on professional practice and gave tutorials. In February 2014 he was a guest lecturer at Falmouth University, he lectured on his own work and gave tutorials.  2013 In June 2013 he gave an interview for Al Jazeera English TV. In the Winter of 2013 Ed lectured at Four Corners Gallery on 'Photographing Protest'. He discussed his involvement with the Occupy movement and The English Defence League. 2012 In October 2012 he spoke about his Occupy London series at the Brighton Photo Biennale and in November 2012 he gave a lecture on his Occupy London series at the Bishopsgate Institute. In November 2012 he wrote an article for The World Photography Organisation on photographing Occupy.

Summary: Professional life began with study as an electrical engineer at the Howard R. Experiences included a variety of land development projects which began as infrastructure and masterplanning projects that trended toward commercial and architectural illumination, before moving to the UK and training/working as a lighting specialist with AECOM. Over time, a strong connection was made with the importance of integrating natural lighting for health and sustainability as well as low-impacting to sensitive ecosystems into the built environment. This includes both architectural integration as well as combining what is naturally or artificially available, day or night, within a lighting design. Integrated design projects covered a variety of diverse locations including the United States, United Kingdom and locations within the Middle East.  Watching the way people interact with their enviroment, there is a great deal of importance with respect to first impressions and long-term opinions people have of their environments. There is no doubt that there are lighting solutions which enhance a person‚Äôs response to the built environment, regardless of the structure, climate or purpose. Particular project experience in the use of natural and artificial lighting of architecture, the public realm, galleries, schools, landscape and roadways. Related projects include daylight modelling and design, overshadowing assessments and night-time lighting impact strategies.

Summary: Allan Howard BEng(Hons) CEng FILE FSLL @illuminator_42 My role is Director for our UK Lighting & Energy Solutions Business. With 39 years‚Äô worth of experience in the application and understanding of light and lighting I provide a group level role providing clients with technical advice and support regarding all aspects of lighting including the impact of artificial light within the environment as well as providing specialist training. Through my involvement with a range of professional bodies including the Institution of Lighting Professionals (ILP) and the International Commission of Illumination (CIE) I lead and contribute to research and investigations aimed at developing International and National light and lighting Standards and good practice. I am well placed to be aware and understand current and forth coming developments in the lighting and environmental sectors. This enables our clients to be future ready and proactive in the development of their lighting specifications, operations and service delivery to meet these developments and changes. I am a Fellow of the Institution of Lighting Professionals (ILP), a Fellow of the Society of Light & Lighting and a past President of the ILP (2011/12). I am still an active lighting industry member chairing and contributing to specialist panels producing national guidance reports on lighting issues (obtrusive lighting, good lighting practice, application of standards to name a few), as well as being a representative on the ILP National Technical Committee. I am the Executive Secretary for the National Illumination Committee (CIE-UK) part of the International Commission of Illumination and Secretary to the UK Lighting Liaison Group.  I am a regular speaker at lighting conferences and contribute to lighting industry technical articles and the development of national / international good practice guidance such as the effects of lighting on fauna and flora. Lately I joined the CIE Technical Committee TC-58 ‚ÄòObtrusive Light from Colourful and Dynamic Lighting and its Limitation‚Äô and am also on the ILP panel developing guidance for Smart lighting columns. Specialties: Light & lighting application & technical support Lighting environmental impact assessments Road and tunnel lighting Energy & carbon reduction strategies Expert witness SMART Cities Infrastructure

Summary: Audio Visual Architect. Worked within the pro-audio industry since 1988. Owned and operated a sound equipment hire company from 1990 - 2005. Joined Element One as UK Sales Director in May 2020 Element One is a family-owned company formed in 2001 and run from a purpose-built design and manufacturing facility in Kuppenheim near Baden-Baden, Germany. As 100% of the design and manufacturing work is carried out in-house, our products are fully customisable to fit any project design brief. Element One are the originators of the motorised monitor screen, and although copied by some, our award-winning products still hold several key patents and unique design features, including the use of two whisper-quiet and precise stepper motors in each screen. Our products are also best in class for quietness, power consumption and weight and come with a five year warranty. Our simple ethos being to combine the highest quality materials available, with the most sleek and ergonomic designs to create the best motorised screens money can buy. Some of the various applications for our screens include conference, training & board rooms, presentation areas, sales and consulting spaces, reception & concierge desks and point of sale. Although predominantly used for video conferencing and boardroom applications, Element One products can be used in any environment, and are particularly practical if a space wasting LCD monitor with all its cables and connections can be replaced with a discreet and space saving motorised screen that can be hidden away inside a desk when not in use. As well as Element One products being ascetically pleasing and user friendly, our company's uncompromising design philosophy incorporates the need for all products to have a low overall power consumption and be free from pollutants. Element One has a London office, so in addition to providing product advice and sales, we can offer on-site assistance, after sales care and service. London office tel: 02072520000 www.elementonescreens.co.uk info@elementonescreens.co.uk Director at AV Systems Ltd  Joined AV Systems in Jan 2015. www.avsystems.co.uk @avsystemsltd

Summary: I was really lucky that my parents were able to empower me to become a fully integrated, independent adult even though I have a serious disability. It all began before I was two when they built me a new kind of powerchair to give me the same level of mobility as other children at that stage: to free me first to be a toddler, so that each developmental step was right there ahead to seize throughout my childhood. They succeeded. I was 'The Wheelchair Toddler'. I am now passionate about making sure that that is still available to every disabled child born now. No patronising compromise. I meet parents who, like my own parents way back when, are not ready to give up their dreams and ambitions for their child just yet. Dragonmobility's vision is to see every disabled person fully integrated in the mainstream world in a practical way.  I don't think there's any experience I've had in my education and career that I don't call upon in my current work. I use my law degree and my corporate finance experience as much as I use my child development GCSE! Running an engineering workshop is much like my theatre production days - it's about bringing everything together behind the scenes to create exquisite moments of joy. We are a not-for-profit which competes with large international corporations; we know every child by name and build them a machine that fits with their (often quite tricky) body, and we provide the expertise of over 30 years to their parents to make that work and keep it working as they grow. We are looking to the child's future: not a medicalised future, but a life and a career and a family and all the things those parents always dreamed of. We need the support of the people who also believe in children's futures. You can help by supporting us at www.patreon.com/dragonmobility

Summary: We make sound sources VISIBLE!  If you're optimising the sound of your product, you can see instantly where annoying frequencies are coming from. If you want to avoid production downtime, you can see exactly which bearings or components are worn, and plan your preventative maintenance. Save energy costs by finding compressed air leaks instantly. Instantly see sources of squeaks and rattles, wind noise, road noise, workplace noise... The SOUNDCAM is the world's first fully portable, splash-proof, battery-powered acoustic-imaging camera. Like thermal imaging but for sound, the SOUNDCAM locates sound sources in real-time superimposed on a video picture.  Previously this revolutionary technology came in the form of complex and fragile hardware and software for experts. Coming on the market in early 2019, the SoundCam is the only acoustic camera that is truly portable and robust, and which anyone can learn to use in 5 minutes.  With 64 microphones measuring at 48kHz, and 100 frames/sec of acoustic pictures, it has pinpoint accuracy and speed that very few can match, for a fraction of the price of other systems.  Priced at ‚Ç¨8k, it is rapidly becoming part of the standard toolkit for anyone working with acoustic issues. This is mind-blowing, game-changing high-tech that anyone can use! For the acoustic experts, we also have the modular BIONIC series of acoustic cameras, with advanced specifications and prices that nobody can come close to.  We also offer rental, and consulting services. With this incredible technology, we can solve your noise problems faster than anyone else! As UK distributor for CAE Software and Systems GmbH, the market leader worldwide, we supply quality made in Germany.

Summary: Miniature Broadcast Cameras Ltd was set up after the sudden demise of Optex December 2005 During my 17 years at Optexl l supplied very small cameras mainly Pulnix which were used in several products including one of the first Cricket Stump Cameras in the World . Although SD  these Cameras were used extensively in Broadcast Television. The Lip Stick Camera was first used in Live Television by TV-AM being placed inside a Parrots cage so the viewer could get the Parrots  POV  The Birds name was Magic so the Lip stick Camera was renamed 'The Magic Cam'  after the Parrot. The 3XCCD Toshiba Camera has been used in many situations over the years and perhaps most famously attached to a Wild Elephant in South Africa.  With full Remote Camera Control the Live pictures were RF linked  to a Helicopter and Land Vehicle . This was the first time ever that a wild Elephant had a Live Linked Camera attached to it's head but, within about 7/10 days the equipment was knocked off and destroyed . Summary: I have found it difficult over the past few years to label what I do. I‚Äôve found myself creating in many different ways, from building brands and websites to curating events, retreats and experiences. I worked as a freelance creative and consultant in London until a few years ago when I took a career break. I loved to create, to build brands and to bring stories and ideas to life, but something was missing for me. I decided to spend some time reconnecting with my passions and finding the parts of my job that I loved the most, I realised that I missed connecting with people and being able to spend time outdoors in nature. During this time I focused on doing the things that bought me happiness, travel, time with friends and family, time outdoors and time spent on self healing and self development. I re-discovered my passion for yoga and decided to pursue a path training as a yoga instructor. Focusing on my wellness and wellbeing has become a non-negotiable part of my daily routine. Every day I take time out for my mental health through daily meditation and breath-work practice and I make time to move my body. I love doing sports that allow me to be outside, surrounded by nature, and over the years I have developed quite a passion for sliding sideways, be it on a snowboard, surfboard or wakeboard. I live in the mountains in the winters and by the sea in the summers, this seasonal lifestyle means I get to travel, do the sports I love and meet inspiring people. I provide my clients with a range of design and movement services in various different ways, Through creative coaching and consultancy I help bring brands and ideas to life and through retreats, workshops and 1-2-1 yoga and mediation sessions I help my clients to integrate wellness methods into their everyday life to improve wellbeing and enhance work performance  I‚Äôve worked with most of my clients from the very start of their journey, helping to bring thier idea to life, giving it shape and helping it to grow into a lifelong passion project. I work in the industries I am passionate about and my clients include; yoga studios, adventure travel brands, ski chalets, ethical clothing brands, snowsports schools and surf retreats to name a few. In addition to working side by side with my clients for many years, I have created several business of my own, a retreat company, MVMT Retreats, a yoga studio, Powder Yoga and a children‚Äôs mindfulness brand, The Feelies. I bring my years of experience from all of these endeavours to every project to help you build and grow your business.

Summary: I was supposed to be an historian I suppose. At least, that's what I studied in Oxford back in the days of flares, prog rock and visions of a better world. Maybe I would have been had I spent less time touring with bands and more time submerged in my studies. But music won and the 1970's were spent building large PA rigs and doing tour production for the likes of Selecter, The Beat and Haircut 100.  Fate intervened once more in 1980 and a period spent managing Roy Harper and launching his record label were followed by a decade at the sharp end of what was then a record industry, managing bands and producers and doing A+R consultancy for the likes of A+M, CBS, MCA and others.  Like all music professionals, part of my accreditation was the Virgin Records rip-off, leading to a nasty legal quagmire feathering the nests of slick lawyers and an accompanying dissillusionment with the record industry but not with music. Refocused if not yet entirely re-energised I returned to recording my own music in the early 1990's, and within the context of assembling my own modest recording rig I found myself sourcing juicy bits of equipment for friends and acquaintances in the industry. As so often in my past, an accidental adjunct to the main event turned into the main event itself and the rest is history. A monster with three heads, Funky Junk now operates from London, Paris and Milan meaning (if nothing else) that I get the occasional good meal and frequent good company. One thing is for sure, though...a life of accidental twists and turns holds other unexpected aventures in store.  At least, I sincerely hope so. Specialties: Pasta.

Summary: Naim founder Julian Vereker MBE (1945-2000) was a racing car driver, entrepreneur and self-taught engineer with a deep passion for music. Not content with second best, he decided to design his own amplifiers and loudspeakers, ignoring accepted wisdom and focusing on aspects of performance that made music burst to life. These first designs laid the foundations for a range of iconic and award-winning hi-fi products that would reach well into the next century.
